Sunway Center for Electrochemical Energy and Sustainable Technology SCEEST Sunway University Malaysia Synergistic integration based on some transition-metal (TM) derived compounds is a unique and appealing technique, especially toward oxygen evolution reaction (OER) under alkaline circumstances. Herein, we present a cobalt-selenide (CoSe2) and cobalt-oxide (Co3O4) based composite (CSCO-2) material through a wet chemical method. As-prepared catalyst has been analyzed for various physicochemical characterizations. CSCO-2 offers efficient OER performance in 1.0 M KOH with an overpotential of 252 mV at current density of 20 mA/cm2, with a low Tafel slope value of 69 mV/dec. Importantly, as-prepared catalyst shows stability of 48 h for longer electrochemical performance as a potential candidate for OER. Graphical abstract Unlabelled Image Keywords Co3O4 CoSe2 Wet chemical Electrocatalyst OER Alkaline media Data availability statement Data available in article supplementary information. 1 Introduction The widespread use of fossil fuels creates a number of issues including depletion of resources, degradation of environment, as well as health issues, leading experts to work on new renewable energy options [1–3]. It is indeed ultimately essential to minimize or remove the usage of fossil fuels, as well as to develop green fuels containing renewable aspects for present and future applications [4,5]. Electrochemical water splitting (EWS) has achieved a considerable value and acknowledged as one of the most efficient and precise approaches for oxygen (O2) and hydrogen (H2) production because of less energy utilization [6]. EWS necessitates the use of effective catalytic materials to carry on both oxygen evolution reaction (OER) as well as hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [7,8]. The effective catalytic substance to drive OER is an important factor to derive kinetics of water splitting [9]. OER is the most difficult two-half cell reaction due to its four protons attached via four electron transfers, making it a slow reaction kinetically [10]. To date, ruthenium oxide (RuO2) and iridium oxide (IrO2) have shown to be the optimum electrocatalysts in OER due to intriguing qualities such as the specifications for lower overpotential values to start the EWS reactions at a faster rate along with superior stability [11]. Nevertheless, their massive prices and rarity are significant barriers to capitalizing them in large-scale applications [12]. This is the primary motivation for developing catalytic materials with reduced Pt concentration or fully Pt-free nonprecious catalysts to advance fuel cell technology. The non-noble three-dimensional (3D) transition metals such as (Ni, Co, Fe, and Mo) as well as their oxides [13,14], sulfides [13,14], carbides [15,16], nitrides [17,18], phosphides [19,20], and alloys have been studied for two decades for synchronous EWS due to their unlimited supply resource production, low cost, and significant catalytic performance [21]. The electrocatalytic activity is enhanced by the capillary contacts of transition metal oxides (TMOs) between the catalysts [22]. TMOs have been extensively used in marketable fuel cells, lithium ion batteries, and supercapacitors due to their potential features [23]. Researchers have studied the synthesis of metallic compounds for electrocatalytic purposes because of availability of several states (metal oxidation), even the distinctive building blocks of ionic species acting as opposing anions attached to these different metals [24]. Since it has been researched and is considered to be an efficient electrocatalyst for the OER process, cobalt oxide (Co3O4) has attracted a lot of attention during the past two decades [23]. Recent study indicates that numerous alterations were required to enhance Co3O4's catalytic activity; nonetheless, cheap cost, easy, additional remedies are still needed to make Co3O4 work normally [25]. Furthermore, current research demonstrates that metal oxides and metal selenides work more effectively as electrocatalysts than transition metal sulfides or phosphides [26]. However, transition metal selenides (TMSe) may act as extremely effective catalysts to overcome the aforementioned water electrolysis problems [27]. Due to their 4s24p4 electronic structure, selenides (Se) atoms are easily able to share electrons with much more electronegative elements to make TMSe or readily accept two electrons from less electronegative elements to produce Se2− ions [28]. TMSe have a large surface area and a high surface concentration of atoms due to their ultrathin layers, which reduces the charge transfer range and encourages the development of water splitting toward OER [29,30]. Metal‑selenium based compounds have superior electrical conductivity and more active edge sites than metal oxides or hydroxides because of their metallic characteristics. This makes them excellent electrocatalysts for OER. With regard to OER, cobalt selenides (CoSe2) in particular are a good competitor because of their capacity for quick proton transfer and electron arrangement that is nearly ideal, which guarantees a mild adsorption strength to oxygen. Numerous morphological forms of CoSe2, including CoSe2 microspheres, hollow core-branch CoSe2, porous CoSe2 nanosheet arrays, and atomically thin CoSe2, have been created due to the materials' demonstrated potential as a highly efficient OER catalyst in reality [31–33]. The simple nature, cheap cost and substantial electrochemical activity of CoSe2 derived electrocatalysts make them effective for water oxidation [34]. These characteristics have led to the development of cobalt-based nanostructures using a range of techniques, including vapor deposition, precipitation, and wet chemical reactions [35–37]. The role of lattice defects, including oxygen vacancies and element partitioning, in controlling the OER in Co3O4 nanostructures has been extensively studied. It has been found that cationic vacancies at octahedral sites in Co3O4 nanosheets (Vx-Co3O4) can increase the number of electrons per Co atom and optimize the adsorption energy of the intermediate product, leading to excellent OER performance [38]. Similarly, the presence of oxygen vacancies in Co3O4 nanorods enhances the electrocatalytic activity, resulting in low overpotential and small Tafel slope value [39]. In addition, the presence of both Co and O vacancies induces the formation of bridge Co sites in rebuilt catalysts, which exhibit a high level of activity in the OER. Within these defects, Co vacancies show a significant OER activity [40]. In this study, we have prepared the CoSe2@Co3O4 composite material through a wet chemical method. The prepared pristine materials (CoSe2 and Co3O4) and their composites have been analyzed for different physicochemical characterizations including; crystallinity, morphology, elemental presence, d-spacing, and chemical bonding via XRD, SEM, EDS, HRTEM, XPS, FTIR, UV–Vis, and Zeta potential, respectively. As-prepared composite (CSCO-2) has shown a promising electrochemical response in alkaline media, with 252 mV as overpotential value to produce 20 mA/cm2 current density. As a result of the effective reaction kinetics, the low Tafel slope value has been calculated as 69 mV/dec. Additionally, the CSCO-2 material has shown an electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) of 490 cm2, which has been calculated through cyclic voltammetry (CV) analysis. Interestingly, the CSCO-2 has demonstrated the stable and durable nature for 48 h. Such physicochemical characterizations along with robust electrochemical performance, strongly suggest this composite as a novel and comparable material for further use in energy conversion/storage applications. 2 Experimental work 2.1 Materials Selenium chloride (SeCl2), cobalt chloride hexahydrate (CoCl2·6H2O), hydrazine hydrate (N2H4), and urea (CH₄N₂O) were obtained through Sigma Aldrich. Each chemical was of the analytical grade and was used promptly. 2.2 Preparation of CoSe2@Co3O4 composites The preparation of CoSe2@Co3O4 composite was done into two stages; Firstly, the CoSe2 was synthesized via hydrothermal method. Wherein, 0.1 M cobalt chloride hexahydrate and 0.1 M selenium chloride precursors were dissolved in 70 mL deionized water (DW) with continuous stirring for 20 min. Then, 20 mL of aqueous N2H4 was added slowly dropwise into prepared precursor solution and followed by vigorous stirring for 30 min. Later, the mixed solution was shifted to 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and kept for 15 h at 180 °C in an electric oven. As the reaction time was completed then it allowed to cool down at room temperature. The precipitates of CoSe2 were washed several times with deionized (DI) water and collected through the filter paper. The CoSe2 precipitates were dried in electric oven at 60 °C for 4 h and collected accordingly. Secondly, the composites of CoSe2@Co3O4 were prepared by aqueous chemical growth process. Where, the precursors of Co3O4 i.e., 0.1 M CoCl2·6H2O and 0.1 M urea (CH₄N₂O) were mixed into 100 mL DI water in 4 beakers separately. Herein, the prepared CoSe2 was added into varying amounts including 0 mg, 40 mg, 80 mg and 120 mg in beakers containing Co3O4 precursors and labeled as Co3O4 pristine, CSCO-1, CSCO-2, and CSCO-3, respectively. After that, these were covered with aluminum foil and sonicated for 30 min. The prepared solutions were placed into an electric oven for precipitation at 95 °C for 5 h. Once the precipitate of CoSe2@Co(OH) formed then it was cooled at room temperature. The precipitates were cleaned with DI water and filtered by ordinary filter paper. After that drying process was carried out at 60 °C for 5 h to remove the moisture content. Furthermore, CoSe2@Co(OH) precipitate was calcined in furnace at 500 °C for 5 h. Finally, CoSe2@Co3O4 composites (CSCOs) were collected and ready for further characterizations as well as electrochemical analysis. 2.3 Physicochemical characterizations As-prepared samples' purity and degree of crystallinity were examined employing a RIGAKU TTR X-ray diffraction (XRD) equipment with a Cu Kα radiation intensity of 0.15406 nm at a 45 kV acceleration rate and a 45-mA current. The software High Score Plus was used to perform quantitative analysis on various samples. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to investigate the morphology of samples using an instrument JEOL JSM-6480 A having an operating voltage of 20 kV. Energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) attached with SEM was used for the elemental analysis of materials. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was applied by using the instrument FEI TECHNNAI G2 for further morphological characteristics in detail. The corresponding lattice fringes have been determined using Image-J software. Chemical attachment of samples was analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using instrument PerkinElmer PH 5100 XPS X-ray photoelectron spectrometer system. Shirley's background was eliminated using the Casa XPS software, and then a combined Gaussian as well as Lorentzian line profile was used for curve fitting. PerkinElmer's Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) equipment was used to observe the chemical bonding properties of electrocatalyst. Lambda-365 UV–vis spectroscopy was used to investigate the absorbance of several materials dispersed in deionized water. Furthermore, Dynamic light scattering (DLS) method was used to analyze the zeta potential of the synthesized materials using Malvern Zeta ZS in the pH range of 1–11. 2.4 Electrochemical analysis 1.0 M potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution has been utilized in order to conduct the desired electrochemical tests with a potentiostat by VERSASTAT4–500. In three-electrode cell system, modified glassy carbon electrode (GCE) has been used as the working electrode, a reference electrode was a silver‑silver chloride (Ag/AgCl) filled with a 3.0 M potassium chloride (KCl) solution, and the counter electrode was a platinum (Pt) wire. To prepare the catalytically active material ink, 5 mg of each prepared catalyst was dissolved in 10 mL of DW and 0.1 mL of 5% Nafion solution. The catalytic slurry was composed of various separate elements such as pure CoSe2, Co3O4, and their composites (CSCOs), which were continuously stirred in an ultrasonic bath for 20–30 min before testing. 5 μL drop of each catalyst (0.2 mg mass) was deposited onto the cleaned GCE surface with 3 mm contact area. Then, the catalyst was dried through the air blower at room temperature. Polarization curves for OER response were examined using linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) with a scan rate of 5 mV. Charge transfer resistance (Rct) for each catalyst was examined using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). EIS was analyzed with experimental parameters of 1.45 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), a sinusoidal potential of 5 mV, and sweeping frequencies from 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz (water oxidation onset potential). Furthermore, the durability of as-prepared catalyst (CSCO-2) was tested for 48 h at two different current densities, 20 and 40 mA/cm2, as a longer electrochemical performance. The ECSA was calculated through the CV curves within non-Faradaic region at various scan rates; 30, 50, 70, and 90 mV/s, respectively. Finally, the Ag-AgCl reference potential was converted into the RHE potential employing the Nernst equation: E RHE = E Ag / AgCl + 0.059 pH + E Ag / AgCl ° By subtracting the thermodynamic potential (onset) of 1.23 V for a water splitting system, the overpotential (ɳ) can be determined from the standard electrode potential of E°(Ag/AgCl) which is 0.2412. Overpotential ղ = Onset potential E RHE V – 1.23 V The Tafel slope, on the other hand, has been computed using the Tafel equation: ղ = b log j + a Where the overpotential is ղ, the Tafel slope is b, and the current density is j. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Physicochemical characterizations The crystallinity of various materials has been analyzed through XRD patterns, as shown in Fig. 1 . It can be seen that the XRD patterns of virgin CoSe2 has well-matched patterns with reference JCPDS no. 00-10-0409 along with sharp and broader peaks at around 33.68°, 37.51°, 43.81°, and 56.86° correspond to (111), (012), (121), and (211) crystallographic planes [41,42]. On the other hand, pristine Co3O4 has broader peak at 31.21°, 36.76, 38.43°, 44.63°, 55.71°, and 59.26° relevant to (220), (311), (222), (400), (422), and (511) crystallographic planes, which is well-matched with reference JCPDS no. 01–078-1969 with some reported research works as well [43,44]. However, the composites of CoSe2 with Co3O4 (CSCO-1 and CSCO-2) have different patterns than both of pure materials, but having existence of both elements within one crystal structure [45]. Interestingly, the addition of CoSe2 into Co3O4 have changed a bit crystallinity of Co3O4 with a slight peak shifting of the corresponding peak at 44.36° [46], which can be seen within the XRD patterns of CSCO-2. This resulting peak shifting feature represents the external force, which has been exerted by the atom of CoSe2 having certain quantity [47]. Through the XRD analysis of various electrocatalytic materials, the successful synthesis of CoSe2@Co3O4 composites (CSCOs) has been confirmed except of any additional impurity. (See Scheme 1.) For morphological features and elemental presence of various electrocatalysts, the SEM equipped with EDS has been executed on various materials, as depicted in Fig. 2 . The pristine CoSe2 can be observed as nano-needle like shape (Fig. 2 a). The agglomerated-particles like structure of CoSe2 can also be compared with these recent research reports [48–51], and the confirmation of desired elements within CoSe2 can be seen via EDS spectra (at the right side of corresponding image), respectively. However, the pure Co3O4 has shown needle-like morphology [52–54], shown in Fig. 2 (b), along with its elemental presence through EDS spectra (right side of SEM image). In contrast, the prepared nanostructures (CSCO-1 and CSCO-2) have revealed as a combination of both morphologies with distinct intensity (as addition of CoSe2) [55,56] (Fig. 2 (c, d)). It is clearly analyzed that the desired growth of Co3O4 nanoparticles on the morphology of CoSe2 has great impact, which can be seen through given images along with their combined morphologies. However, the presence of CoSe2 nanoparticles embedded with Co3O4 nanoneedles can be distinguished through the intensive amount of CoSe2 in the CSCO-2 as compared to CSCO-1 via SEM images as well as EDS spectra, correspondingly. Various SEM results along with EDS have strongly suggested successful growth of Co3O4 on CoSe2 in terms of morphology with varied number of elements within the composites [57]. The HRTEM was also applied to get deep morphological details of various materials at their nanoscale. Fig. 3 shows the HRTEM images along with FFT to validate their interplanar distance (d-spacing) as well. Fig. 3(a) reveals nanoparticles like structural based image of pristine CoSe2, and yellow region at the right side reveals the high magnified image with d-spacing calculation. The d-spacing value of CoSe2 has been calculated as 0.270 nm [58]. However, the Co3O4 has shown nanoneedles as previously confirmed through SEM images [59]. Interestingly, the d-spacing of pristine Co3O4 has been determined as 0.272 nm (as shown right side of the corresponding image within yellow region). In comparison, both CSCO-1 and CSCO-2 have different deep morphologies as well as d-spacing calculations, due to varying amount of CoSe2 [46]. The d-spacing values have been calculated as 0.277 and 0.285 nm for CSCO-1 and CSCO-2. It is observed that the addition of CoSe2 with different ratios have created some internal forces within the crystal, which resulted some external forces between the planes [60,61]. Such findings through HRTEM analysis support this composite with dual nature of CoSe2 and Co3O4, which can be an essential reason for synergistically derived effect between both elements to enhance electrochemical performance for OER [62]. Fig. 4 depicts the XPS results to analyze the chemical state as well as surface composition of various materials including CoSe2 and CSCO-2. The Fig. 4(a) shows pristine CoSe2's Co 2p signals which are exhibiting four doublets owing to Co 2p3/2 as well as Co 2p1/2 commitments. These spectra match well with reference study on cobalt spinel phase [63]. Contrarily, the corresponding peaks at 779.55, 780.25, and 785.20 eV signal in Co(OH)2 are all attributed to Co3+, and Co2+ respectively [64]. Proceeding on to Fig. 4(b), the Se 3d spectrum shows two strong binding energy components at 60.11 eV and 62.00 eV, most likely originating on the catalyst's surface from the selenium‑oxygen bonds [65]. Furthermore, two major peaks at 55 eV as well as 56.50 eV attributes to Se 3d3/2 properties [66]. Fig. 4(c) demonstrates the slight variation in the binding energy between two distinct materials. The O 1 s signal shows a significant discrepancy (Fig. 4d). The spectrum decomposition reveals three contributions: the first, with a binding energy of approximately 530.13 eV, attributed to surface lattice oxygen species (OLat) in cobalt spinel; the second, with a binding energy of approximately 531.03 eV, attributed to low coordination oxygen species (O2, O2 and O) or surface oxygen species fully absorbed over the surface oxygen vacancy (OSurf); and the third, with a binding energy of approximately 532 eV (represented as OChe) [67]. As per the literature, OSurf has better mobility than OLat, which enhances the overflow phenomenon at the solid surface [68]. In addition, Fig. 4 (e and f) displays the survey spectrum of both CoSe2 and CSCO-2. The FTIR characterization technique has been used to determine the functional groups and characteristic vibrations of as-synthesized materials. Herein, Fig. 5 revealed that the common broader peak at 1400 to 1500 cm−1 and 3200–3600 cm−1, these peaks were observed due to OH− stretching. For pristine Co3O4, the bands at 660 and 570 cm−1 are showing the M − O stretching vibrations. The existence of M-O bands provides significant proof for the formation of the Co3O4 spinel network [69]. The stretching bands at 660 cm−1 and 570 cm−1 linked to the Co2+ − O and Co3+ − O bonds, respectively. These bands confirmed that the Co2+ and Co3+ were tetrahedrally and octahedrally coordinated. However, the FTIR spectrum of CoSe2 pristine exhibited the vibration band at 700 to 800 cm−1 attributed to CoSe bond [42]. In addition, These CoO and CoSe stretching vibrations are both available in the CSCO-1 and CSCO-2 samples that validate the formation of CoSe2@Co3O4 (CSCOs) composites. Furthermore, the broadening of bands was also revealed in CSCO-2 due to higher amount of CoSe2. The obtained results and supported literature [70], thus confirmed the formation of metallic spinel structure [71,72]. UV–Vis absorbance spectrums of CoSe2, Co3O4, CSCO-1 and CSCO-2 composites were determined at room temperature as shown in Fig. (S1). The CoSe2 shows one absorption band in the range of 265–280 nm. However, UV spectrum of Co3O4 revealed two significant absorption bands in the range of 730–770 and 420–550 nm. These absorbance bands maybe as a result of the charge transition effect from the ligand to the metal as O2− → Co3+ for 730–770 nm, while O2− → Co2+ for 420–550 nm wavelength. These bands signified the transfer processes of Co3+and Co2+ with oxygen. Furthermore, it has been analyzed that both CoSe2 and Co3O4 absorption bands were observed in CSCO-1 and CSCO-2, which give the evidence for the formation of CoSe2@Co3O4 (CSCOs) nanostructures [73]. Moreover, the zeta potential measurements of prepared electrocatalysts were determined in aqueous media, shown in Fig. (S2). It is observed that the zeta potential measurements of Co3O4, CoSe2, CSCO-1, and CSCO-2 catalyst exhibits zeta −16.4, −20.8, −25.3, and − 31.6 mV, respectively. As it is analyzed, all samples contain negative charged zeta potential. While, CSCO-1 and CSCO-2 have increased negatively charged zeta potential. In CSCO-2, it happened due to the negative charged Co3O4 surface is surrounded by capping ions of another negatively charged CoSe2 surface. Thus, it creates strong electrostatic repulsion of composites. From given results, it is stated that the CSCOs contain higher colloidal stability because of interaction with CoSe2 in Co3O4 [74,75]. 3.2 Electrochemical performance The electrochemical OER response of each material like CoSe2, Co3O4, CSCO-1, and CSCO-2 can be seen through LSV curves, as shown in Fig. 6 (a). Overall, the OER response has been recorded in 1.0 M KOH through three electrode arrangements (above discussed in detail). It has been observed that the pristine Co3O4 has least response for OER with an overpotential value of 365 mV, regrettably, because of its limited active sites and disorganized surface features, its higher energy limitation is the main challenge [40]. However, the CoSe2 has a better response as compared to Co3O4 in terms of onset potential, having an overpotential of 335 mV [42]. Moreover, the prepared composites have shown much better electrochemical response for OER with an overpotential of 288 and 252 for CSCO-1 and CSCO-2, respectively. Notably, all the overpotential values have been calculated at 20 mA/cm2 current density. All the corresponding overpotential values can be seen in histogram (Fig. 6 b). While the other composite material (having 120 mg of CoSe2 (CSCO-3)) has also been analyzed for OER (with an overpotential of 294 mV), as shown in supplementary information (Fig. S3). Additionally, the OER mechanism's rate-determining step was assessed from the linear range of LSV through applying Tafel slope equation, as well as the calculation was performed in accordance with previously published work [46], as shown in the Fig. 6(c). The Tafel slope values have been calculated as 115, 74, 97, and 69 mV/dec for Co3O4, CoSe2, CSCO-1 and CSCO-2. Four electron transfer processes are involved in the water oxidation, and the alkaline reaction's general stages are summarized by the following key steps: [25]. (1) M + OH − → MOH + e − (2) MOH + OH − → MO − H 2 O (3) MO − → MO + e − (4) 2 MO → 2 M + O 2 + 2 e − Tafel values of 120, 60, 40, as well as 15 mV/dec are related with theoretical Tafel analyses for the determination of OER system. The presented research (this work) is supported by step 3, which might be regarded as the rate limitation phase for the oxidation of water in an alkaline environment. It is worth noting that electrochemical behavior of as-received materials is highly related to materials' durability as long-term applicability. As a result, the chronopotentiometry experiment was carried out for 48 h to test the stability of the as-synthesized CSCO-2 electrocatalyst at 20 and 40 mA/cm2 current density values (shown inside Fig. 6 (d)). While, the durability of as-synthesized material (CSCO-2) has been tested through the LSV, before and after chronopotentiometry, as depicted in Fig. 6(d). It is also noticed that the prepared material (CSCO-2) is well-stable and durable with a negligible change in chronopotentiometry results and LSV curves, in terms of overpotential behavior for OER response in alkaline media. After conducting confirmation of material's chemical transformation, several analyses were carried out including post SEM, EDS, HRTEM, and XRD analysis. Corresponding post-analysis results demonstrated that there was minimal alteration in the morphology, chemical composition, and crystal structure of the composite material (CSCO-2) following chronopotentiometry, as illustrated in supplementary Fig. (S4). We have applied CV at various scan rates such as 30, 50, 70, and 90 mV/s within non-faradaic region, for the calculation ECSA, to compare active sites of the composite toward superior OER response, as shown in Fig. (S5 a-d). However, the ECSA has been calculated through the given expression: ECSA = C dl / C s In the given expression, Cs (specific capacitance) is in 0.04 mF/cm2 for KOH electrolyte, and Cdl has been calculated by linear fitting of current density vs scan rates as shown in Fig. 6 (e). The ESCA values for different electrocatalytic materials have been calculated as 42.5, 160, 232.5, and 490 cm2 for Co3O4, CoSe2, CSCO-1, and CSCO-2 accordingly, as mentioned in Table 1 . Moreover, the EIS is an important strategy to analyze the charge transfer system between both electrolyte as well as electrode material. In this regard, the Nyquist plots have been executed to analyze the Rct values of the materials including pristine and their composites, as illustrated in Fig. 6 (f). However, the Bode plots have provided phase features of different catalysts at various frequencies (Fig. S5 e-f). The Rct values of various materials have been calculated as 494, 310, 114, and 64 Ω for Co3O4, CoSe2, CSCO-1, and CSCO-2, respectively. Faster charge transfer at the electrolyte/electrode interface was encouraged by CSCO-2's due to lower charge transfer value, which led to favorable water oxidation. Table 1 presents a summary of results obtained from LSV, ECSA, and EIS analyses. The table depicts that the CSCO-2 composite's electrochemical performance is better than that of many other materials examined in the study, making it a very efficient material toward energy conversion and storage mechanism. Additionally, a comparison of synthesis route, morphology, Tafel slope and overpotential value of CSCO-2 has been conducted with recently reported electrocatalysts (Table 2 ). According to the analysis, the CSCO-2 composite performs better than recently published studies in terms of low overpotential and Tafel slope values. The Co3O4 contain higher binding energy of OH* (ΔEOH). In order to significantly reduce the binding energy of OH* (ΔEOH) without altering binding energy of O*(ΔEO), Se and Co vacancy work together to tailor the electronic states of Co3 and Co2 to a nearly optimum value. This lowers the catalytic overpotential. Unlocking the catalytic potential of diverse catalysts for a range of electrochemical reactions appears possible through the appropriate combination of multiple defect structures [76]. This improvement in performance is attributed to the in-situ growth of CoSe2 with the desired amount, which has been proven to be a contributing factor for enhancing the water oxidation performance onto Co3O4 in alkaline. 4 Conclusions In summary, the resulting composites of cobalt-selenide (CoSe2) and cobalt-oxide (Co3O4) (CSCOs) have been successfully prepared through hydrothermal accompanied wet chemical method. The prepared CSCOs have been characterized for their crystallinity through XRD, and it is confirmed that the corresponding materials do not have any other impurity with well-defined crystal structure. However, the morphology and elemental presence have been estimated through SEM/EDS and HRTEM. While, the chemical bonding of desired materials has been analyzed through the XPS and FTIR, respectively. As-prepared material (CSCO-2) demonstrated the electrochemical performance with a lower overpotential value of 252 mV at current density of 20 mA/cm2, and a Tafel slope value of 69 mV/dec. In addition, the CSCO-2 showed a low charge transfer resistance (Rct) value of 64 Ω, and a double layer capacitance (Cdl) value of 19.6 μF/cm2 which has been calculated from the cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests at various scan rates. Interestingly, as-prepared CSCO-2 catalyst has also revealed a durable nature for 48 h, except of any major change in potential with respect to current densities. The combination of oxides and selenides has contributed to create active sites within the composite as synergistic effect to promote the electrochemical activity for OER. The material CSCO-2 exhibits promising physical characteristics and electrochemical features, such as lower overpotential and Tafel slope values, that provide compelling evidence for its potential suitability as a candidate for energy conversion and storage devices. coredata.dc:description: Synergistic integration based on some transition-metal (TM) derived compounds is a unique and appealing technique, especially toward oxygen evolution reaction (OER) under alkaline circumstances. Herein, we present a cobalt-selenide (CoSe2) and cobalt-oxide (Co3O4) based composite (CSCO-2) material through a wet chemical method. As-prepared catalyst has been analyzed for various physicochemical characterizations. CSCO-2 offers efficient OER performance in 1.0 M KOH with an overpotential of 252 mV at current density of 20 mA/cm2, with a low Tafel slope value of 69 mV/dec. Importantly, as-prepared catalyst shows stability of 48 h for longer electrochemical performance as a potential candidate for OER.
